Award.AwardTitle: Precision Timing of the Periodic Radio Flares from Ultracool Dwarf Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to probe the internal structures and magnetic properties of ultracool dwarfs (UCDs) using precise timing of radio flares observed with the Arecibo radio telescope. UCDs are unusual objects which straddle the star-planet boundary. This group includes the lowest mass stars and brown dwarfs, and UCDs have temperatures ranging from about 1600-2700 K. Like many gas-giant planets and brown dwarfs, these relatively cool objects are thought to have dust clouds, and may generate magnetic fields through a rotating, convecting and electrically conducting fluid (also known as a 'magnetic dynamo'). Short-term periodic outbursts are observed at radio wavelengths, and in some cases their period decreases over time, sometimes very abruptly. The PI plans to analyze data showing these abrupt decreases in order to test models about the objects? interior structure, and also may be applicable to brown dwarfs and giant gas planets modeling. The PI plans to involve undergraduate female and underrepresented minority students, and provide them with well-structured opportunities to gain experience with plasma physics, astrophysics, observational techniques, advanced data analysis and instrumentation.

The planned radio detection of the UCDs provides a direct means to measure the field strength, topology and stability of low mass stars. Preliminary work by the PI shows that flaring period of two UCDs have been steadily decreasing, and that phase jumps have been observed a few months apart. After each jump, the period shortens significantly. This work will test whether it can be explained by differential rotation of the stars, in a manner analogous to sunspots in other main sequence stars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to investigate a possibility that the periodic radio flares from very low mass stars and brown dwarfs can be used to investigate rotational properties of these objects. Rotation plays a critical role in the generation and stability of the magnetic fields, which drive stellar activity that critically affects planetary habitability. This is particularly important in the case of cool, low-mass stars, in which case planets must orbit close enough to them, in order to be habitable. As these stars are typically much more active than those similar to our Sun, close-in planets are exposed to frequent flaring, which can make them permanently or temporarily uninhabitable. 

In this program, we have monitored radio flaring from a very low-mass star, TVLM 513, for one year, at time intervals ranging from one day to several weeks, using the Arecibo radio telescope at the observing frequency of 5 GHz. Our measurements have shown that the star undergoes alternating periods of enhanced activity and relative quiescence, each lasting several months, This sets an approximate timescale for flaring activity that would be experienced by a potentially habitable planet orbiting such a star. During the six-month period of a relative quiescence, the star emitted only one radio flare during its ~1.96-hour rotation period. The flare’s periodic appearance could be predicted with a ~10 s precision, which confirms the star’s utility as a clock, whose behavior can indeed serve as means to study details of stellar rotation and hence its magnetic activity. Similarly, this clock-like property of the star can be used to detect a presence of substellar-mass companions around it, just as the transit or radial velocity methods are used to hunt for planets around solar-type stars. In the case of TVLM 513, our data rule out a presence of bodies more massive than ~10 Jupiter masses with orbital periods between one to six months. Such measurements and analyses can be extended to other periodically flaring stars during the extended episodes of the apparent flaring period stability.

Finally, a large database of high quality radio observations of flares from TVLM 513, accumulated over the duration of this program, will serve an an excellent material for further studies of magnetospheres, radio emission mechanisms, and magnetic activity of very low-mass stars.
